Expectation1: Be considerate with shared spaces and boundaries
Situation1: Trash pickup is tomorrow and the bins are only half-full with plenty of room left.
Expectation2: Educate the public and the community about their cause.
Situation2: You are scheduled to be a guest on a live radio show to discuss your cause, and the segment starts in five minutes.
Story:
I glanced at the clock—five minutes until my live radio segment. My heart thudded with anticipation; this was my chance to talk about waste reduction and responsible consumption, to inspire real change. As I rehearsed my opening lines, I heard the familiar clatter outside. Peeking through the window, I saw my neighbor dragging our half-full trash bins to the curb. We’d agreed to only put them out when full, to reduce unnecessary pickups and set an example for the block. I knew she expected me to help, to be a good neighbor and respect our shared commitment to the environment and our community’s rules.

But the radio host’s voice echoed from my phone, “We’ll be live in three minutes.” My activist side screamed that this was the moment to reach a wider audience, to educate and advocate. Yet, as a neighbor, I felt the weight of our agreement and the unspoken expectation to be present, to uphold our shared values in small, everyday actions. My hands trembled as I stood between the door and my phone, torn by the demands of both roles, feeling the pressure mount as the seconds ticked away.
